all_paragraphs: ‘Data Science’ is an extremely broad term. It encompasses data visualization, data analysis, data engineering, data modeling, and more. In cases where you’re more focused on data visualizations and data analysis, integrals may not be necessary.

However, for those who want to get into prediction modeling and hypotheses testing, integrals are a fundamental building block to being a data scientist. It will be extremely useful to know the basics of integration if you plan to learn about statistics and probability distributions in greater detail.
By the end of this article, you’ll understand the fundamental ideas of integrals, the basic properties of integrals, and common antiderivatives that will be useful to know.
Imagine that we wanted to find the area under the curve above between the two points a and b. One method that we can do is approximate the area under the curve using rectangles.

Notice how the more rectangles we use to approximate the area under the curve, the more accurate the approximation is. If we took the area of the four rectangles on the right, it will approximate the area under the curve much better than the two rectangles on the left.

There are 4 main ways that you can use the Riemann sum, but we’re going to focus on the left Riemann sum, the right Riemann sum, and the midpoint Riemann sum. The difference between the three is that they simply determine what the height of each rectangle should be (the y-value).

Now that you understand what the definite integral represents, we’ll look at the essential fundamentals of integrals. Don’t worry, they’re super simple to understand, so don’t feel intimidated. First, we’ll look at the two fundamental theorems of calculus (which is what makes integration useful), and then we’ll look at several properties of integrals.
This basically tells us how we can calculate the area under a curve once we find the integral of the equation.

This theorem essentially means that the integral is the antiderivative, meaning that it is the opposite of finding the derivative. It tells us that there’s a relationship between integrals and derivatives.

The area above a curve and up to the x-axis is negative. For example, if you wanted to get the integral of the function above between points a and b then the area would be equal to negative ten instead of ten.
The integral of a single point, c, is equal to zero. This makes sense because the area of a line is zero if you think about it!
The integral of a constant times a function is equivalent to the constant times the integral of a function.
An integral with swapped bounds (a and b) is equal to the negative integral.
The integral of f(x) plus the integral of g(x) is equal to the integral of f(x) plus g(x).
The definite integral from point a to point c is equal to the sum of the integral from point a to point b and the integral from point b to point c.
